chunk_text: In addition to their sense of smell, hearing, and electroreception, sharks also rely on their keen eyesight to detect prey., In addition to their sense of smell, sharks also rely on their keen sense of hearing to detect prey., Sharks possess a variety of sensory adaptations that enable them to locate and capture their food in the vast expanses of the ocean., Sharks have specialized sensory organs called the lateral line system, which runs along the length of their bodies and helps them detect vibrations and movements in the water., Overall, sharks have a remarkable array of sensory adaptations that enable them to detect and capture prey in their aquatic environment., ```Sharks are fascinating creatures that have evolved over millions of years to become efficient predators in the marine ecosystem., This system allows sharks to sense the movements of nearby fish and other marine animals, helping them locate potential prey even in low visibility conditions., The olfactory bulbs in a shark's brain are large and well-developed, allowing them to process and analyze different scents efficiently., Sharks have a highly developed olfactory system that allows them to detect minute traces of blood and other chemicals in the water., Furthermore, sharks also use their sense of touch to detect prey., Another important sensory adaptation that sharks possess is their ability to detect electrical signals given off by other organisms., Sharks have well-developed eyes that are adapted to low light conditions, allowing them to see clearly even in murky waters., By utilizing these sensory abilities, sharks are able to navigate the complexities of the ocean and secure their place as top predators in the marine food chain.```, Sharks have a network of specialized cells called the ampullae of Lorenzini, which are located in their heads and snouts., Sharks have sensitive receptors called the lateral line, which run along their bodies and detect changes in water pressure and movement., Some species of sharks, such as the great white shark, have a specialized structure called the tapetum lucidum behind their retinas, which enhances their ability to see in low light., One of the primary ways in which sharks detect prey is through their keen sense of smell., This sense of smell is so acute that some species of sharks can detect a single drop of blood in an Olympic-sized swimming pool., This sensory system helps sharks locate prey that may be swimming nearby, even if they are not visible to the naked eye., This unique ability allows sharks to detect the presence of prey that may be hiding or camouflaged, giving them a distinct advantage when hunting.

entity.name: Sharks
entity.description: A group of fish with a cartilaginous skeleton, known for their predatory behavior and sensitive sensory systems.;;;A large marine predator known for its keen sense of smell.;;;A group of fish with a cartilaginous skeleton, known for their predatory behavior and specialized sensory systems.;;;A group of fish characterized by a cartilaginous skeleton, five to seven gill slits on the sides of the head, and pectoral fins that are not fused to the head.;;;A large predatory shark known for its size and power, often associated with attacks on humans.;;;A group of fish with a cartilaginous skeleton, known for their predatory behavior in the ocean.;;;A group of cartilaginous fish that are apex predators in marine ecosystems.;;;A group of fish that have evolved over millions of years to become efficient predators in the marine ecosystem.;;;A group of fish with a cartilaginous skeleton, known for their predatory behavior and well-developed sensory systems.;;;A group of cartilaginous fish that are known for their predatory behavior and sensory abilities.;;;A group of fish known for their acute sense of smell and ability to detect minute amounts of blood in water.;;;A group of fish with a cartilaginous skeleton, known for their predatory behavior and keen senses.;;;A group of fish with a cartilaginous skeleton, known for their predatory behavior and sensory systems.;;;A group of fish with a cartilaginous skeleton, known for their predatory behavior and highly developed senses.;;;A group of fish with cartilaginous skeletons and cold-blooded metabolism.;;;A group of fish with cartilaginous skeletons and powerful jaws, known for their predatory behavior in marine environments.;;;A group of fish known for their cartilaginous skeletons, powerful jaws, and predatory behavior.;;;A group of fish known for their predatory behavior and sensory capabilities.;;;A group of fish with a cartilaginous skeleton, known for their predatory behavior and sensory adaptations.
